topic.title: HPE Helion Development Platform 2.0: ALS Operations Guide
topic.abstract: Documentation to help operate the Application Lifecycle Service.This section contains usage requirements - additional requirements needed to successfully operate an Application Lifecycle Service (ALS) cluster.

sectiondiv.p: ALS AZs do not automatically align to HPE Helion OpenStack AZs. It is important that they are configured the same in order for the applications to be distributed correctly. You can set the availablity zone for a node by using “kato node availabilityzone $ZONE --node $IP” command. Additional references: http://docs.stackato.com/admin/cluster/zones.html https://docs.hpcloud.com/devplatform/2.0/helion/admin/reference/kato-ref.html#topic39432__kato-command-ref-node-availabilityzone
ALS cluster users can connect to internal databases by leveraging the dbshell (recommended) and tunnels (only for sql server) via the helion cli. For more information read this document.
They can also access external,managed databases and message brokers provided by the Database and Messaging Services by specifying database credentials in user provided services instances.

Note that applications in ALS must have line of sight to the database endpoints that they are trying to reach. In the default reference architecture, all of the database instances were created on the same network that the ALS cluster nodes were.

ALS 2.0 supports Docker Apps. Docker Apps are Docker containers that are web apps and expose a port. From an ALS cluster operator perspective two major considerations need to be referred:
The Internal Docker Registry – ALS uses this registry for caching and improving the developer experience. This registry lives in the cloud controller nodes. ALS fetches images from the Docker Hub or the specified repository and keeps copies in a local registry server on the controller so that subsequent deployments using any of the downloaded layers can be done more quickly. A cron job runs periodically to keep the local registry server from growing too large. The size limit is defined in the following setting in kato config and it’s default value is 10240MB. (10GB)
Controlling developer deployments – due to security considerations it is recommended that container deployments are done from a trusted source and from in ALS Organizations with sudo access. It is the operator’s discretion to allow container deployments and they are disabled by default. For more information read this doc: http://docs.hpcloud.com/#devplatform/1.3/helion/admin/server/docker.html

Support for applications using Microsoft .NET technologies has been added to Helion Stackato in HDP V1.2. This allows .NET developers to deploy applications to an Helion Stackato cluster with the the same advantages of Platform-as-a-Service such as automatic build packs, application scaling and monitoring that Linux application developers have.

For details of .NET and Visual Studio versions, application frameworks and software requirements, refer to following references:
https://docs.hpcloud.com/devplatform/1.3/windows/windows_overview.html#topic24073_2__apps
https://docs.hpcloud.com/devplatform/1.3/windows/windows_overview.html#topic24073_2__softwarerequirements

For licensing reasons there are some additional steps an administrator needs to take in order to add .NET and Microsoft SQL Server to the Helion Stackato environment. The administrator will use their own licensed Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2 ISO image and volume license keys to create the glance images by using the new glazier tool.

Glazier has a number of uncommon requirements that should be considered. The glazier tool must be run either from a Linux (Ubuntu recommended) or MAC OSX system that has hardware-based virtualization support enabled and Oracle VirtualBox 4.3.26 or later installed. That system also requires a network connection to the public internet and to the Helion OpenStack where the Helion Stackato cluster will be deployed.

The full list of requirements is:
System running either Linux (Ubuntu recommended) or MAC OS X.
Virtualization support enabled o 16GB RAM recommended
100GB available disk space
Connectivity to the public internet
Connectivity to the Helion OpenStack environment where the Windows images will be deployed ·
Glazier tool downloaded
Oracle VirtualBox 4.3.26 or later installed
Additional downloads o Windows
VirtIO Image 0.1.96: https://fedorapeople.org/groups/virt/virtio-win/direct-downloads/archive-virtio/virtio-win-0.1.96/virtio-win-0.1.96.iso
Windows Server 2012 R2 ISO (either Volume licensed obtained via MSDN for development & test or volume-licensed production images obtained through the Microsoft OEM channel)
Windows Product Key for Windows Server 2012 R2, Standard Edition.
OpenStack RC file for an admin account from your Helion OpenStack environment
Helion OpenStack CA Certificate (ephemeralca-cacert.crt)
For full information on creating .NET and MSSQL database support, see http://docs.hpcloud.com/#devplatform/2.0/windows/windows_building_and_deploying.html
